Located on the south side of Lane Avenue, just west of campus, the interior takes on a very stylistic and minimalist feel, with all-white walls, concrete floors, and simple, modern tables and chairs. They cater to a fast-and-casual type of crowd, filling the niche one step above that of a fast-food restaurant. The restaurant was impeccably clean and the service was as friendly and welcoming as I could ask for. Having mentioned it was my first time in their establishment, each of the various cooks took the time to explain each option and ingredient, recommending their favorite combinations as I moved down the line. As mentioned above, the ordering procedure is the same as Chipotle - get in line and get ready to choose from a series of progressive options. You begin by selecting your format (piada, pasta bowl, or chopped salad bowl). If you choose the piada, you get to watch them grill your bread right in front of you on the griddle as a bonus. Then, you move on to your choice of meat (chicken, steak, Italian sausage, salmon, Italian deli meats, or veggies). After your base has been completed, your other selections encompass pasta (yes or no), your sauce or salad dressing (a basic pomodoro, the spicy diavolo, red pepper or basil pesto, parmesan, etc), your cheese (parmesan, feta, or fresh mozzarella), and finally any and/or all of their selection of 10-12 additional veggie options (roasted red peppers, artichoke hearts, grilled onions, olives, etc.). Additionally, you can add a side dish of fried calamari, spinach and artichoke dip, or one of 4 flavors of piada sticks - which are rolled and baked piada breads that form an almost crunchy breadstick great for dipping in their parmesan sauce. Prices are very reasonable, as well, with most entrees ranging from $5-7, depending upon your meat selection, with the sides in the $2-3 range. You pay and pick up your food at the register, and then clean your own table once you've finished. Piada certainly isn't fancy or pretentious. It is, however, fresh, fast, and a welcomed deviation from the typical fare. Whether you're on your way to catch a Buckeyes game or just taking a break between classes, I'd recommend swinging over to see what the buzz is all about. Enjoy. The atmosphere was simple, clean and very refreshing - too many restaurants fill their walls with crap. Each of the staff members were friendly, and more importantly, quick to fill our requests. I ordered the pasta bowl with chicken, basil pesto, grilled zucchini, shaved parm, olives, tomatos, and cucumber. My friend had the pasta as well, but with the Italian sausage, instead. The only change I'll make on my next visit is that I'll hold off on the basil pesto - it was tasty, but made with far too much garlic for my liking. For Italian under $6 - there isn't much to complain about. Over the last six months, I feel like the quality of product they are using has really declined. Maybe a different supplier or a different kitchen staff is to blame for the downward slide. On my most recent visit a month ago, I was disgusted with the oily texture and taste of the grilled chicken. Some of the vegetable offerings even tasted like they were dipped in oil and set out to be served. I left feeling sick after eating the salad topped with grilled chicken and red sauce - my stomach doesn't lie. On a related note, I make fresh Italian food at my home on a regular basis and it is damn good. If I am not going to have food that is as good or better than mine served to me, then why would I dine out in the first place? My time and money are much better off replicating the ingredients used at Piada. There are plenty of other slower, Italian eaterys around Columbus that are worth your time. 2 out of 3 found this review helpful November 14, 2010 Likes it Good Food, Good Price by Coris ( 9 reviews ) Had the angel hair pasta bowl with salmon, pomodoro sauce, roasted red peppers, artichoke hearts, parmesan, and the artichoke and spinach dip with chips.
